concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or anything you'd like to talk about today.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling kinda overwhelmed with my workload lately, like it’s non-stop, and I’m not sure how to keep up without burning out.

That sounds really challenging, and it's understandable to feel overwhelmed with so much on your plate. How do you envision your life looking if you managed to find a balance between your workload and personal time?

Honestly, I'd love to have a bit more free time to just relax or do something fun without feeling guilty or stressed about what I should be working on. Maybe go back to having a weekend day that's actually mine, like to catch up with friends or just chill.
That sounds like a meaningful goal to work towards, having that personal time back. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident are you that you can make some changes to move towards that balance?
client: Probably around a 4 or 5. I mean, I want to make changes, but it feels like there's so much to juggle, and I’m not sure where to even start.
It's great that you're considering making changes, even though it seems daunting. What do you think could help increase your confidence from a 4 or 5 to maybe a 6 or 7?

client: I think maybe having a more structured plan for my week could help, like carving out specific times where I don't touch work at all. Also, getting some support or tips on how to manage my time more effectively might boost my confidence a bit.

Therapist: Those sound like really practical steps towards creating more balance. It seems like having a structured plan and support for time management could really make a difference. What might be the first small step you could take to start exploring one of these ideas?

Maybe I could start by setting aside a couple of hours on one day this week where I don't do any work, like a mini-break to see how it feels. I could also look into time management resources or talk to some of my peers to see what they do to balance things out.

Setting aside a couple of hours for a mini-break and exploring time management resources or peer advice sounds like a great start. Would you like to set a specific day for your mini-break and identify a resource or person to connect with for time management tips? This could help you take those first steps towards the balance you're aiming for.

Yeah, setting a specific day would probably make me more likely to actually follow through, so maybe I'll pick Thursday since it seems like a good day to take a breather. As for the time management tips, I could reach out to that one classmate who always seems super organized and ask for some advice this week.

It sounds like you've got a solid plan lined up, and Thursday will be your dedicated time to take that well-deserved breather. Reaching out to your organized classmate for advice is a fantastic idea—it shows you're proactive about finding what works for you. Remember, it's perfectly okay to take time for yourself, and you're making positive strides towards balance. As we wrap up, know that I'm here to support you as you explore these changes. Let's touch base next time to see how your mini-break went and any insights you gained from your conversation with your classmate. You've got this!
Thanks, I really appreciate your support. I'll definitely keep you posted on how it goes.
